news_summary: Astronomers have uncovered a massive gaseous bridge linking two galaxies, while scientists have found potential signs of ancient life preserved within Mars' frozen vortex.
news_summary_fr: Des astronomes ont découvert un pont gazeux massif reliant deux galaxies, tandis que des scientifiques ont trouvé des signes potentiels d'une vie ancienne préservée dans le vortex gelé de Mars.
news_summary_es: Los astrónomos han descubierto un enorme puente gaseoso que une dos galaxias, mientras que los científicos han hallado posibles signos de vida antigua conservados en el interior del vórtice helado de Marte.

articles.title: Astronomers discover a gigantic bridge of gas connecting two galaxies
articles.summary: Researchers from The University of Western Australia node at the International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research (ICRAR) have uncovered a colossal bridge of neutral hydrogen gas linking two dwarf galaxies, which spans an astonishing 185,000 light-years between galaxies NGC 4532 and DDO 137, located 53 million light-years from Earth.
articles.content:
Scientists at The University of Western Australia's node of the International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research (ICRAR) have made a remarkable discovery: a massive structure stretching about 185,000 light-years between two galaxies, NGC 4532 and DDO 137, located some 53 million light-years from Earth.

According to a study published in the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, the team also detected a huge tail of gas extending another 1.6 million light-years beyond the bridge, making it the largest feature of its kind ever recorded.

Lead researcher Professor Lister Staveley-Smith from ICRAR UWA explained that the finding provides an important new insight into how galaxies influence each other.

"Our modeling showed that the tidal forces acting between these galaxies, alongside their proximity to the massive Virgo cluster of galaxies, played a crucial role in the gas dynamics we observed," Professor Staveley-Smith said.

He added that as the galaxies orbited one another and moved toward the superheated gas cloud surrounding the Virgo cluster, which reaches temperatures about 200 times hotter than the Sun's surface, they experienced "ram pressure." This effect stripped gas from the galaxies and heated it as they passed through the dense environment.

"The process is akin to atmospheric burn-up when a satellite re-enters the Earth's upper atmosphere, but has extended over a period of a billion years," he said.

"The density of electrons and the speed at which galaxies are falling into the hot gas cloud are enough to explain why so much gas has been pulled away from the galaxies and into the bridge and surrounding areas."

The discovery was made as part of the Widefield ASKAP L-band Legacy All-sky Survey (WALLABY), a large-scale project that maps hydrogen gas throughout the Universe using the ASKAP radio telescope, owned and operated by CSIRO, Australia's national science agency.

Co-author Professor Kenji Bekki of ICRAR UWA said the team identified the enormous gas structures through high-resolution observations of neutral hydrogen, a key ingredient in star formation.

"Neutral hydrogen plays a crucial role in the formation of stars, making this finding fundamental to understanding how galaxies interact and evolve, particularly in dense environments," Professor Bekki said.

Professor Staveley-Smith said the system had strong similarities with our own Milky Way and Magellanic System, providing a unique opportunity to study such interactions in detail.

"Understanding these gas bridges and their dynamics provides critical insights into how galaxies evolve over time, how galactic gas is redistributed, and the varying conditions under which galaxies may or may not form stars," he said.

"This contributes to our broader understanding of the most massive structures in the Universe and their life cycles, which helps us grasp more about their vast complexities and history of star formation."
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery of a massive gas bridge between two galaxies, providing new insights into galaxy interactions and evolution. This breakthrough enhances understanding of star formation and cosmic structures, with broad implications for astronomy and astrophysics.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers find huge gas bridge linking two distant galaxies
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study how galaxies interact and share gas, which helps us understand how stars form and galaxies change over time.

**What happened** – Researchers at The University of Western Australia, part of the International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research (ICRAR), discovered a giant bridge of neutral hydrogen gas stretching about 185,000 light-years between two small galaxies called NGC 4532 and DDO 137. These galaxies are located 53 million light-years away from Earth. They also found an even longer tail of gas extending 1.6 million light-years from this bridge.

**Impact** – This is the largest gas structure of its kind ever recorded. The discovery shows how gravity and pressure from a nearby massive group of galaxies, the Virgo cluster, pull gas between galaxies. This gas is important because it helps form new stars. Studying this bridge helps scientists understand how galaxies change and grow, and how star formation happens in space.

**What’s next step** – The team will continue to study this gas bridge and similar structures using the ASKAP radio telescope in Australia. This will help them learn more about the forces shaping galaxies and the conditions needed for stars to be born.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A massive gas bridge connecting two galaxies reveals new details about how galaxies interact and create stars in the Universe.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des astronomes découvrent un pont géant de gaz entre deux galaxies lointaines
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient comment les galaxies interagissent et partagent du gaz, ce qui aide à comprendre comment les étoiles se forment et comment les galaxies évoluent.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université d’Australie-Occidentale, membre du Centre international de recherche en astronomie radio (ICRAR), ont découvert un gigantesque pont de gaz hydrogène neutre d’environ 185 000 années-lumière reliant deux petites galaxies appelées NGC 4532 et DDO 137. Ces galaxies se trouvent à 53 millions d’années-lumière de la Terre. Ils ont aussi trouvé une queue de gaz encore plus longue, de 1,6 million d’années-lumière.

**Impact** – C’est la plus grande structure de gaz de ce type jamais enregistrée. Cette découverte montre comment la gravité et la pression d’un groupe massif de galaxies proche, l’amas de la Vierge, tirent le gaz entre les galaxies. Ce gaz est important car il aide à former de nouvelles étoiles. Étudier ce pont aide les scientifiques à comprendre comment les galaxies changent et grandissent, et comment les étoiles naissent dans l’espace.

**Prochaine étape** – L’équipe va continuer à étudier ce pont de gaz et d’autres structures similaires grâce au radiotélescope ASKAP en Australie. Cela leur permettra d’en apprendre plus sur les forces qui façonnent les galaxies et les conditions nécessaires à la naissance des étoiles.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un immense pont de gaz reliant deux galaxies révèle de nouveaux détails sur la façon dont les galaxies interagissent et créent des étoiles dans l’Univers.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos descubren un enorme puente de gas que conecta dos galaxias lejanas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian cómo las galaxias interactúan y comparten gas, lo que ayuda a entender cómo se forman las estrellas y cómo cambian las galaxias con el tiempo.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Australia Occidental, parte del Centro Internacional de Investigación en Radioastronomía (ICRAR), descubrieron un gigantesco puente de gas hidrógeno neutro que se extiende unos 185,000 años luz entre dos galaxias pequeñas llamadas NGC 4532 y DDO 137. Estas galaxias están a 53 millones de años luz de la Tierra. También encontraron una cola de gas aún más larga que llega a 1.6 millones de años luz desde este puente.

**Impacto** – Esta es la estructura de gas más grande de este tipo que se ha registrado. El descubrimiento muestra cómo la gravedad y la presión de un grupo masivo de galaxias cercano, el cúmulo de Virgo, atraen el gas entre las galaxias. Este gas es importante porque ayuda a formar nuevas estrellas. Estudiar este puente ayuda a los científicos a entender cómo las galaxias cambian y crecen, y cómo nacen las estrellas en el espacio.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo seguirá estudiando este puente de gas y otras estructuras similares usando el radiotelescopio ASKAP en Australia. Esto les ayudará a aprender más sobre las fuerzas que moldean las galaxias y las condiciones necesarias para que nazcan las estrellas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Un enorme puente de gas que conecta dos galaxias revela nuevos detalles sobre cómo las galaxias interactúan y crean estrellas en el Universo.

articles.title: A clue to ancient life? What scientists found inside Mars’ frozen vortex
articles.summary: Mars’ north polar vortex locks its atmosphere in extreme cold and darkness, freezing out water vapor and triggering a dramatic rise in ozone. Scientists found that the lack of sunlight and moisture lets ozone build up unchecked. This discovery, made with data from ESA’s and NASA’s orbiters, could reveal clues about Mars’ past atmospheric chemistry and potential for life.
articles.content:
Scientists have recently captured a rare look at the harsh winter conditions swirling above Mars' north pole. Inside the planet's polar vortex, temperatures drop dramatically -- much colder than the air outside -- and the continuous darkness of the long Martian winter allows ozone levels in the atmosphere to rise sharply.

"The atmosphere inside the polar vortex, from near the surface to about 30 kilometers high, is characterized by extreme cold temperatures, about 40 degrees Celsius colder than outside the vortex," said Dr. Kevin Olsen of the University of Oxford, who presented the results at the EPSC-DPS2025 Joint Meeting in Helsinki.

At these extreme lows, the small amount of water vapor in Mars' atmosphere freezes and settles onto the polar ice cap. This change has a striking effect on ozone levels. Normally, ozone is destroyed when it reacts with molecules formed as ultraviolet sunlight breaks apart water vapor. But when the vapor freezes out completely, those reactions stop. With nothing left to break it down, ozone begins to build up inside the vortex.

"Ozone is a very important gas on Mars -- it's a very reactive form of oxygen and tells us how fast chemistry is happening in the atmosphere," said Olsen. "By understanding how much ozone there is and how variable it is, we know more about how the atmosphere changed over time, and even whether Mars once had a protective ozone layer like on Earth."

The European Space Agency's ExoMars Rosalind Franklin rover, scheduled to launch in 2028, will search for traces of ancient life on the planet. If Mars once had an ozone layer shielding its surface from ultraviolet radiation, that protective barrier could have made it far more hospitable to life billions of years ago.

How Mars' Polar Vortex Forms

Mars' polar vortex develops as part of its seasonal cycle, driven by the planet's 25.2-degree axial tilt. Like Earth, the Red Planet experiences seasonal shifts, and as northern summer ends, a swirling vortex forms above the pole and lingers until spring.

On Earth, the polar vortex can sometimes destabilize and drift south, sending cold air into lower latitudes. A similar process can occur on Mars, giving researchers valuable chances to study the vortex's interior.

"Because winters at Mars' north pole experience total darkness, like on Earth, they are very hard to study," says Olsen. "By being able to measure the vortex and determine whether our observations are inside or outside of the dark vortex, we can really tell what is going on."

Probing the Vortex

Olsen works with ESA's ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter that is in orbit around Mars. In particular, the spacecraft's Atmospheric Chemistry Suite (ACS) studies Mars' atmosphere by gazing at the Red Planet's limb when the Sun is on the other side of the planet and is shining through the atmosphere. The wavelengths at which the sunlight is absorbed give away which molecules are present in the atmosphere and how high above the surface they are.

However, this technique doesn't work during the total darkness of martian winter when the Sun doesn't rise over the north pole. The only opportunities to glimpse inside the vortex are when it loses its circular shape but, to know exactly when and where this is happening, requires additional data.

For this, Olsen turned to the Mars Climate Sounder instrument on NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter to measure the extent of the vortex via temperature measurements.

"We looked for a sudden drop in temperature -- a sure sign of being inside the vortex," said Olsen. "Comparing the ACS observations with the results from the Mars Climate Sounder shows clear differences in the atmosphere inside the vortex compared to outside. This is a fascinating opportunity to learn more about martian atmosphere chemistry and how conditions change during the polar night to allow ozone to build up."
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery about Mars' polar vortex and ozone buildup, which enhances understanding of Mars' atmospheric chemistry and potential past habitability. This has broad significance for planetary science and the search for ancient life, supported by detailed data from ESA and NASA missions.
articles.personality_title: Scientists discover ozone buildup in Mars’ frozen north polar vortex
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Mars has a north polar vortex, a swirling area of very cold air that forms during its long winter. This vortex traps the atmosphere in darkness and extreme cold, creating unusual conditions compared to the rest of the planet.

**What happened** – Researchers using data from the European Space Agency’s (ESA) and NASA’s orbiters studied Mars’ north polar vortex. They found that inside this vortex, temperatures drop about 40 degrees Celsius lower than outside. The cold freezes water vapor, stopping it from breaking down ozone gas. Without water vapor to destroy it, ozone builds up in large amounts.

**Impact** – This discovery helps scientists understand how Mars’ atmosphere changes in winter and how ozone behaves there. Ozone is important because it shows how chemical reactions happen in the air. If Mars had a protective ozone layer in the past, it might have shielded the surface from harmful radiation, which is key to knowing if life could have existed.

**What’s next step** – ESA’s Rosalind Franklin rover, planned for launch in 2028, will look for signs of ancient life on Mars. The new findings about ozone and the polar vortex will guide scientists in studying Mars’ past atmosphere and its ability to support life.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have found that Mars’ cold, dark north polar vortex lets ozone build up, revealing clues about the planet’s past atmosphere and its potential to have supported life.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques découvrent une accumulation d'ozone dans le vortex polaire nord gelé de Mars
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Mars possède un vortex polaire nord, une zone tourbillonnante d’air très froid qui se forme pendant son long hiver. Ce vortex emprisonne l’atmosphère dans l’obscurité et un froid extrême, créant des conditions inhabituelles par rapport au reste de la planète.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs utilisant des données des orbiteurs de l’Agence spatiale européenne (ESA) et de la NASA ont étudié le vortex polaire nord de Mars. Ils ont découvert qu’à l’intérieur de ce vortex, les températures chutent d’environ 40 degrés Celsius par rapport à l’extérieur. Le froid gèle la vapeur d’eau, l’empêchant de détruire l’ozone. Sans vapeur d’eau pour le dégrader, l’ozone s’accumule en grande quantité.

**Impact** – Cette découverte aide les scientifiques à comprendre comment l’atmosphère de Mars change en hiver et comment l’ozone se comporte. L’ozone est important car il montre comment les réactions chimiques se produisent dans l’air. Si Mars avait autrefois une couche protectrice d’ozone, elle aurait pu protéger la surface des radiations nocives, ce qui est essentiel pour savoir si la vie a pu exister.

**Étape suivante** – Le rover Rosalind Franklin de l’ESA, prévu pour un lancement en 2028, recherchera des traces de vie ancienne sur Mars. Ces nouvelles découvertes sur l’ozone et le vortex polaire guideront les scientifiques dans l’étude de l’atmosphère passée de Mars et sa capacité à soutenir la vie.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les scientifiques ont découvert que le froid et l’obscurité du vortex polaire nord de Mars permettent à l’ozone de s’accumuler, révélant des indices sur l’atmosphère passée de la planète et son potentiel à avoir abrité la vie.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos descubren acumulación de ozono en el helado vórtice polar norte de Marte
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Marte tiene un vórtice polar norte, una zona giratoria de aire muy frío que se forma durante su largo invierno. Este vórtice atrapa la atmósfera en oscuridad y frío extremo, creando condiciones inusuales en comparación con el resto del planeta.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores que usaron datos de las naves espaciales de la Agencia Espacial Europea (ESA) y la NASA estudiaron el vórtice polar norte de Marte. Descubrieron que dentro de este vórtice, la temperatura baja alrededor de 40 grados Celsius más que afuera. El frío congela el vapor de agua, impidiendo que destruya el ozono. Sin vapor de agua que lo descomponga, el ozono se acumula en grandes cantidades.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento ayuda a los científicos a entender cómo cambia la atmósfera de Marte en invierno y cómo se comporta el ozono. El ozono es importante porque muestra cómo ocurren las reacciones químicas en el aire. Si Marte tuvo una capa protectora de ozono en el pasado, podría haber protegido la superficie de la radiación dañina, algo clave para saber si pudo existir vida.

**Próximo paso** – El rover Rosalind Franklin de ESA, planeado para lanzarse en 2028, buscará señales de vida antigua en Marte. Los nuevos hallazgos sobre el ozono y el vórtice polar ayudarán a los científicos a estudiar la atmósfera pasada de Marte y su capacidad para sostener vida.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los científicos encontraron que el frío y la oscuridad del vórtice polar norte de Marte permiten que el ozono se acumule, revelando pistas sobre la atmósfera pasada del planeta y su potencial para haber sostenido vida.
